after that there is a feature in HTTP 2 called server push that would be the first time that servers are actually

of the requests and responses is going to have a header with just meta information about that request or
response along with the body that has the actual content so I do a lot of mentoring for
new web developers and so I like to show them what an actual get request looks like in case they haven't seen one on
the wire I think it helps answer questions they might have about you know do I know client resolution do I know
how many colors the client supports no I mean this is all that gets sent up from a client to a server as far as when the
server is going to make decisions this is all that it's going to see so typical request will have a get so I'm just I
want to retrieve something from this URL in this case the client is specifying it
wants to use HTTP 1.1 these are the other headers that get transmitted along and we'll look at these as we go but
except langu is just saying this is the language I have my browser configured for so if you happen to have a
multilingual website that's how the server knows what language to respond with we'll see the user agent as we go
through some stuff everybody lies right they have all sorts of things in there that they really aren't but just to
advertise usually there's one thing you can key into to tell you what that specific browser is I don't personally
do a lot of browser sniffing on servers but if you need to take advantage of that for some reason we'll talk about
encoding later we get into performance that just says the client supports compression and the host header lets the
server know which of the particular sites it needs to route to so if you're using IIs like I am the host header lets
me use a single IP address for all the sites that I have it actually sees that host header in the request and it knows
which one of the I sites it needs to serve okay so that's what a basic get request looks
like if we look at a typical response we'll see the server did indeed Say it'll use HTTP 1.1 200 just means that

super simple tool tool specifically for HTTP that makes it as easy as what you
just saw here's the full request here's the full response so he worked on that parttime

CSS JavaScript and images it downloads them all they close the browser they come back tomorrow what I'd like to do
is if I haven't changed any of those things I'd like to have it served right off their own machine I mean it's sitting in their browser cache on their
machine it's never going to get faster than to use that if you don't set expirations on your content to tell it
how long the stuff is considered fresh your browser has to guess and a lot of times times it's going to go back to the
server and say I have a file I got yesterday has it been changed since then and since you have 104 requests or
whatever on a typical web page that's 104 trips back to your web server to find out that nothing actually changed
so we set expirations for all of our images for 30 days our JavaScript and CSS we do for a year because we have
version numbers built into them that way when you come and revisit tomorrow you don't have to download any of those
images again okay if it turns out I really have to change the logo I'll just change the name to logo one.
